climbs.name: Yolks on You
climbs.fa: L. Bertelsen, J. Wereb, T. Birkenstock - March 2020

content.description: The Coop may finally be full.  The newest addition ascends a highly featured chert slab before you set off up the blunt arete via technical and delicate climbing.  Save some gas for the end or the yolk will be on you.  This one gets real right before the chains.
content.location: Leftmost route in The Coop.  Belay from the trail.

content.description:
Who doesn't like a winner, or a chicken dinner for that matter?  

 This route will throw all kinds of tricks your way.  Begin with moderate layback moves and high feet.  The laybacks give way to small pods and pockets just before the angle kicks back and holdable features become sparse.  Get funky with your knees and learn to love underclings if you have any hope of making it through the crux.  The climbing stays pumpy until the end, and one could surely blow it above the most difficult moves.  The end of this climb is a true cherry on top with some amazing mail slots and bullet stone on the grey arete. 

 If not for the fuzzy rock through the first few bolts of this climb I think this would get four stars.  The movement and holds are amazing.

 It's finger lickin' good!
content.location: Currently the rightmost route in The Coop.

content.description: Begin by mounting three tiers of ledges. The last of which requires a spectacular mantle. From here big pulls on sculpted pockets will lead you to a hold at the top of the spine. Now the fun begins. Tackle a nails hard crux sequence that lasts for two bolts through a sloper with a chert nodule thumb catch, narrow slot crimps, chert knobs, an undercling, high feet, and ends in stab to a unique pocket off desperate feet in a subtle dihedral. A small climb that will leave you feeling spatchcocked!
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains. Unclip the first draw after you clip the second for your belayers comfort.
content.location: This route ascends the short but prominent spine on the left side of the back wall of The Coop.

content.description: Spread your legs and use your feet. This climb is a gift that keeps on giving. If things are getting too intense, shhhhhh.... calm your mind, a jug is in your future.
content.location: Left side of the coop with a high first bolt. Don't be a hero use a stick clip!

climbs.name: Prize Rooster
climbs.fa: Luke Bertelsen, Kemper Brightman, Jilian Wereb - July 2018

content.description:
It'll take more than brute strength to take home the blue ribbon on this climb.

Prize Rooster climbs the stunningly clean, featured, and steep dihedral on the left side of The Coop.  With thoughtful stemming sequences and amazing features for the entire 70 feet it's easy to see why this one won the prize.

 This climb has some of the best limestone around, and is sure to be popular.
content.location: One route right of Queen of the Coop.

climbs.name: Lucky Wishbone
climbs.fa: Kemper Brightman, Luke Bertelsen - Bolt camp 2018

content.description: Begin by stick clipping the first bolt and making your way to the base of the crack. Follow the crack to it's terminus and pull left onto the ledge. Clip the bolt in the roof and head left through a couple thin holds and a slot that deposit you at an incut but hidden jug. Move back right and cruise past two more bolts up the slab.  Like the namesake restaurant, this route might not get four stars on yelp, but it still tastes damn good if you're in the mood.
content.location: The left of the two routes on the right side of the coop. The right most route is 'winner wwinner'. The route climbs the flake feature to the roof, and the slab above.

climbs.name: Look at all those Chickens
climbs.fa: Luke Bertelsen, Tiffany Bertelsen, Kemper Brightman, Jilian Wereb, Cory Hanson - July 2018

content.description:
We weren't sure what we were going to get with this one, but despite some limestone holds that are a little rough on the hands, this one turned out great.  

 Begin by mounting a small ledge.  The climbing becomes strenuous almost immediately with almost no down pulling holds and culminates in a tricky lip encounter before pulling on to a final slab that is the top third of the route.  

 This route has so many different types of holds on it and quite a few very fun and engaging sequences.

 Lastly, if you haven't seen this gem:

youtube.com/watch?v=F-X4SLh…
content.location: The furthest right climb on the back wall of The Coop.

climbs.name: Flippin' The Bird
climbs.fa: Kemper Brightman, Luke Bertelsen, Jillian Wereb.  July 2018

content.description: Start on an incut rail in light colored rock below a large black flake. Ride the flake for a few moves, clip the second bolt and decipher your transition left onto the slab. Once established on the slab, continue through delicate moves past the third bolt in a section of lower angle rock to a slot above. From the slot, clip the fourth bolt and commit to the final crux of the route. The problem can be solved by going either left or right past the fifth bolt.
content.location: Begins below a large flake on the black slab of the coop. The first route right of the ovious pocketed corner of "All Cooped Up"

climbs.name: Cold Chicken and Cheese
climbs.fa: Luke Bertelsen, Kemper Brightman, and Cory Hanson - Summer 2018

content.description:
What else do you need really?  Some would argue vegetables, but I say who needs 'em.  In a rural part of the country one might find entire gas station coolers dedicated to just these two amazing food staples.  

Cold Chicken and Cheese packs a lot of climbing into 50 ft.  It starts with some tech funk before easing off through the middle section that deposits you at a nice rest just before the final boulder problem - exactly how will you get yourself over to those juicy chert nodules?  Solve the riddle and climb the final spicy runout section on your way to glory.  A shiny surprise waits near the chains.  

 I won't ruin it for you.
content.protection: 6 bolts to lower off anchor.  There is a chain draw on the difficult to hang second bolt.
content.location: This is the middle climb and the only one with a fixed chain draw (bolt 2).

content.description:
If you'd have told me another quality line could be squeezed out of the back wall of The Coop I wouldn't have believed it........., but here it is nonetheless.  The newest line just between Cold

Chicken and Cheese and Look at all those Chickens is another technically challenging and thoughtful climb that packs a lot of action into just over 40 feet.  

 Despite what it might look like from the ground this one has the hardest moves of the climbs on the back wall and ends with real puzzle as you look for a way on to the final chert slab before the anchors.
content.location: Begins just left of Look at all those Chicken and a short pillar at the base of the wall.

climbs.name: All Cooped Up
climbs.fa: Kemper Brightman, Luke Bertelsen, Jillian Wereb.  On an ideal 100 degree day in July 2018

content.description:
All Cooped Up climbs the obvious series of pods and pockets in the back left corner of the Coop. Creatively stem and press your way up the first half of the route using a variety of holds along the way. Where the angle steepens, the route turns up the heat, and a couple longer moves between good holds are required before reaching the chains. 

 Established on a 100 degree day in the summer, the name is a reference to the feeling of being trapped in the shade of the coop, unable to fathom the brutally sunny hike back to the car at the end of the day
content.location: All Cooped Up is the series of light colored pods in the back left corner of The Coop, adjacent to the black slab

content.description:
The Coop is the alcove just left (east) of the Bowling Alley, where the majority of the initially developed routes at the Farmhouse were. The Coop features routes ranging from 5.9 to 5.12d. Currently climbing exists on every wall in this jam packed little cove. Routes range from 45 to 85 ft.

 Due to the cylindrical nature of The Coop, there are almost always two to three walls in the shade throughout the summer months. Winter will almost certainly mean dark times for this sector as well as the rest of the north walls of the farmhouse. While development is welcome in this area, please contact the existing developers before assuming a project has been completed, or starting a new route.
